animalOfTheDay.name: salmon
facts: After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.
Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.

calendar.name: red panda
facts: They are endangered, with fewer than 10,000 left in the wild due to habitat loss.
Red pandas are solitary and mark territory with scent glands on their feet.
They have a false thumb, an extended wrist bone, to help grip bamboo.
Red pandas are not closely related to giant pandas but share a bamboo-heavy diet.

calendar.name: rhinoceros
facts: Rhinos have thick skin, but it can be sensitive to sunburn and insect bites, leading them to wallow in mud.
They communicate through grunts, snorts, and even infrasound below human hearing.
All five rhino species are threatened by poaching, with three critically endangered.
Rhino horns are made of keratin, the same protein as human hair and nails.

calendar.name: robin
facts: Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.
They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'

calendar.name: rook
facts: Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.
They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.
Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.

calendar.name: sable
facts: They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.

calendar.name: salmon
facts: Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.

randomAnimals.name: stork
facts: In folklore, storks are said to deliver babies, a myth originating in Europe.
Storks are known for their long legs and necks, which help them wade through water to catch prey.
They are mute and communicate by clattering their bills together.
Storks are monogamous and often return to the same nest year after year.

randomAnimals.name: louse
facts: Nit combs from ancient Egypt (1500 BCE) show humans long battled infestations.
Lice die within 24 hours off a host, needing blood meals every 4-6 hours.
They've infested humans for 5 million years, evolving alongside hominids.
Head lice glue eggs (nits) to hair shafts with waterproof cement stronger than epoxy.

randomAnimals.name: puffin
facts: Puffins are seabirds with colorful beaks that brighten during mating season.
They can carry dozens of small fish crosswise in their beaks at once.
Puffins are excellent swimmers, using their wings to 'fly' underwater.
They nest in burrows on cliffs and return to the same site year after year.
